trans-unit.source: Using the Resource Designer tool
trans-unit.target: Using the Resource Designer tool

trans-unit.source: Applies To: Windows PowerShell 4.0, Windows PowerShell 5.0
trans-unit.target: Applies To: Windows PowerShell 4.0, Windows PowerShell 5.0

trans-unit.source: The Resource Designer tool is a set of cmdlets exposed by the **xDscResourceDesigner** module that make creating Windows PowerShell Desired State Configuration (DSC) resources easier.
trans-unit.target: The Resource Designer tool is a set of cmdlets exposed by the **xDscResourceDesigner** module that make creating Windows PowerShell Desired State Configuration (DSC) resources easier.

trans-unit.source: The cmdlets in this resource help create the MOF schema, the script module, and the directory structure for your new resource.
trans-unit.target: The cmdlets in this resource help create the MOF schema, the script module, and the directory structure for your new resource.

trans-unit.source: For more information about DSC resources, see [Build Custom Windows PowerShell Desired State Configuration Resources](authoringResource.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information about DSC resources, see [Build Custom Windows PowerShell Desired State Configuration Resources](authoringResource.md).

trans-unit.source: In this topic, we will create a DSC resource that manages Active Directory users.
trans-unit.target: In this topic, we will create a DSC resource that manages Active Directory users.

trans-unit.source: Use the [Install-Module](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn807162.aspx) cmdlet to install the **xDscResourceDesigner** module.
trans-unit.target: Use the [Install-Module](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn807162.aspx) cmdlet to install the **xDscResourceDesigner** module.

trans-unit.source: **Note**: **Install-Module** is included in the **PowerShellGet** module, which is included in PowerShell 5.0.
trans-unit.target: **Note**: **Install-Module** is included in the **PowerShellGet** module, which is included in PowerShell 5.0.

trans-unit.source: You can download the **PowerShellGet** module for PowerShell 3.0 and 4.0 at [PackageManagement PowerShell Modules Preview](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=49186).
trans-unit.target: You can download the **PowerShellGet** module for PowerShell 3.0 and 4.0 at [PackageManagement PowerShell Modules Preview](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=49186).

trans-unit.source: Creating resource properties
trans-unit.target: Creating resource properties

trans-unit.source: The first thing we need to do is decide on properties that the resource will expose.
trans-unit.target: The first thing we need to do is decide on properties that the resource will expose.

trans-unit.source: For this example, we will define an Active Directory user with the following properties.
trans-unit.target: For this example, we will define an Active Directory user with the following properties.

trans-unit.source: Parameter name Description
trans-unit.target: Parameter name Description

trans-unit.source: **UserName**: Key property that uniquely identifies a user.
trans-unit.target: **UserName**: Key property that uniquely identifies a user.

trans-unit.source: **Ensure**: Specifies whether the user account should be Present or Absent.
trans-unit.target: **Ensure**: Specifies whether the user account should be Present or Absent.

trans-unit.source: This parameter will have only two possible values.
trans-unit.target: This parameter will have only two possible values.

trans-unit.source: **DomainCredential**: The domain password for the user.
trans-unit.target: **DomainCredential**: The domain password for the user.

trans-unit.source: **Password**: The desired password for the user to allow a configuration to change the user password if necessary.
trans-unit.target: **Password**: The desired password for the user to allow a configuration to change the user password if necessary.

trans-unit.source: To create the properties, we use the **New-xDscResourceProperty** cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To create the properties, we use the **New-xDscResourceProperty** cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: The following PowerShell commands create the properties described above.
trans-unit.target: The following PowerShell commands create the properties described above.

trans-unit.source: Create the resource
trans-unit.target: Create the resource

trans-unit.source: Now that the resource properties have been created, we can call the **New-xDscResource** cmdlet to create the resource.
trans-unit.target: Now that the resource properties have been created, we can call the **New-xDscResource** cmdlet to create the resource.

trans-unit.source: The **New-xDscResource** cmdlet takes the list of properties as parameters.
trans-unit.target: The **New-xDscResource** cmdlet takes the list of properties as parameters.

trans-unit.source: It also takes the path where the module should be created, the name of the new resource, and the name of the module in which it is contained.
trans-unit.target: It also takes the path where the module should be created, the name of the new resource, and the name of the module in which it is contained.

trans-unit.source: The following PowerShell command creates the resource.
trans-unit.target: The following PowerShell command creates the resource.

trans-unit.source: The **New-xDscResource** cmdlet creates the MOF schema, a skeleton resource script, the required directory structure for your new resource, and a manifest for the module that exposes the new resource.
trans-unit.target: The **New-xDscResource** cmdlet creates the MOF schema, a skeleton resource script, the required directory structure for your new resource, and a manifest for the module that exposes the new resource.

trans-unit.source: The MOF schema file is at **C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules\Demo_DSCModule\DSCResources\Demo_ADUser\Demo_ADUser.schema.mof**, and its contents are as follows.
trans-unit.target: The MOF schema file is at **C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules\Demo_DSCModule\DSCResources\Demo_ADUser\Demo_ADUser.schema.mof**, and its contents are as follows.

trans-unit.source: The resource script is at **C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules\Demo_DSCModule\DSCResources\Demo_ADUser\Demo_ADUser.psm1**.
trans-unit.target: The resource script is at **C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\Modules\Demo_DSCModule\DSCResources\Demo_ADUser\Demo_ADUser.psm1**.

trans-unit.source: It does not include the actual logic to implement the resource, which you must add yourself.
trans-unit.target: It does not include the actual logic to implement the resource, which you must add yourself.

trans-unit.source: The contents of the skeleton script are as follows.
trans-unit.target: The contents of the skeleton script are as follows.

trans-unit.source: Updating the resource
trans-unit.target: Updating the resource

trans-unit.source: If you need to add or modify the parameter list of the resource, you can call the **Update-xDscResource** cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: If you need to add or modify the parameter list of the resource, you can call the **Update-xDscResource** cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: The cmdlet updates the resource with a new parameter list.
trans-unit.target: The cmdlet updates the resource with a new parameter list.

trans-unit.source: If you have already added logic in your resource script, it is left intact.
trans-unit.target: If you have already added logic in your resource script, it is left intact.

trans-unit.source: For example, suppose you want to include the last log in time for the user in our resource.
trans-unit.target: For example, suppose you want to include the last log in time for the user in our resource.

trans-unit.source: Rather than writing the resource again completely, you can call the **New-xDscResourceProperty** to create the new property, and then call **Update-xDscResource** and add your new property to the properties list.
trans-unit.target: Rather than writing the resource again completely, you can call the **New-xDscResourceProperty** to create the new property, and then call **Update-xDscResource** and add your new property to the properties list.

trans-unit.source: Testing a resource schema
trans-unit.target: Testing a resource schema

trans-unit.source: The Resource Designer tool exposes one more cmdlet that can be used to test the validity of a MOF schema that you have written manually.
trans-unit.target: The Resource Designer tool exposes one more cmdlet that can be used to test the validity of a MOF schema that you have written manually.

trans-unit.source: Call the **Test-xDscSchema** cmdlet, passing the path of a MOF resource schema as a parameter.
trans-unit.target: Call the **Test-xDscSchema** cmdlet, passing the path of a MOF resource schema as a parameter.

trans-unit.source: The cmdlet will output any errors in the schema.
trans-unit.target: The cmdlet will output any errors in the schema.
